newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan builds largest superconductive generator.
newsitem.headline: Japan builds largest superconductive generator.

text.p: An association comprising power firms and generator makers in Japan has completed construction of the world's largest superconductive power generator, said a government affiliate which commissioned the work.

"Operations of the (experimental) unit will start in the autumn, and commercial application of the technology is expected to begin sometime in the 2010s," a spokesman for the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organisation (NEDO) said on Wednesday.

About 1.1 million kilolitres (6.9 million barrels) of crude oil would be saved per year if superconductive generators were introduced to all the existing thermal and nuclear power plants in Japan, the spokesman said.
NEDO has been conducting experiments on superconductive technology since 1988 in an effort to lessen Japan's heavy dependence on imported oil.
Generators using superconductive electric wire on their coils would raise efficiency of power generation by about one percent, compared with conventional units using copper wire.
The new experimental generator in Osaka, western Japan, uses niobium-titanium, which turns superconductive when frozen to minus 269 degrees Celsius.

The eight-billion-yen unit, with a generation capacity of 70,000-kilowatt (kw), was built by Engineering Research Association for Superconductive Generation Equipment and Materials under the commission from NEDO.

The association is composed of power generator manufacturers, electric wire makers, research firms and electric utilities, including Tokyo Electric Power Co Inc, Kansai Electric Power Co Inc and Chubu Electric Power Co Inc.
